Award.AwardTitle: The Russia-Japan-USA Symposium on Fundamental & Applied Problems of Terahertz Devices & Technologies. Held June 17-21, 2014, University at Buffalo, NY.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The Russia-Japan-USA Symposium on Fundamental and Applied Problems of Terahertz Devices and Technologies will be held June 17-21, 2014 at the University at Buffalo, NY. It will address research areas in the field of interaction of THz radiation with micro- and nanostructures and advanced solid-state THz emitters and sensors, including novel device concepts. This conference will foster advances in the leading research on various types of Terahertz technology, by gathering a diverse group of experts, researchers and students. The program provides the opportunity for scientific exchanges and discussions on exciting breakthroughs in the terahertz field and the understanding the underlying physical mechanisms. It will promote interactions between leading researchers in USA, Japan, and Russia on terahertz devices and technologies and will focus on the technical challenges and barriers of transitioning the research results into the THz system-level applications. The highlights of the symposium will be accessible worldwide through the symposium proceedings.

PREFACE

 

 

The Russia–Japan–USA Symposium on Fundamental & Applied Problems of Terahertz Devices and Technologies "RJUS TeraTech-2014" was the third in the series of annual meetings on Fundamental and Applied Problems of Terahertz (THz) Devices and Technologies. It took place on June 17-21, 2014 at the University at Buffalo, NY, USA. Leading experts in THz science and technology from the US, Japan, Russia, and other countries have discussed issues ranging from basic THz-related phenomena to applications in sensing, imaging, and communications.  The scope of the symposium included interaction of THz radiation with micro- and nanostructures and advanced solid-state THz emitters and sensors. RJUS gathered experts from academia, industry, and government agencies. They reviewed the recent exciting breakthroughs and their underlying physical mechanisms.

The mission of the symposium was to foster interactions between researchers in USA, Japan, and Russia working in the area of Terahertz Devices & Technologies. The symposium addressed not only the recent original results but will dealt with the technical challenges and barriers of transitioning the research results into the THz system-level applications.

Dr. V. Mitin, Vladimir Mitin, Distinguished Professor at the University at Buffalo was General Chair of the Symposium. Professors Taiichi Otsuji of Tohoku University, Valery E. Karasik of Bauman Moscow State Technical University, Michael Shur of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Junichiro Kono of Rice University served as co-Chairs and Members of the Organizing Committee. Professor Victor Ryzhii of Tohoku University was the Program Chair. Professors Andrea Markelz of University at Buffalo, and Akira Satou of Tohoku University, and Stanislav Yurchenko of Bauman Moscow State Technical University were the Members of the Program Committee. Professors Andrei Sergeev and Nizami Vagidov of the University of Buffalo were Local co-Chairs. Mr. Tim Yore was Assistant to the Local Organizing Committee.

The Proceedings include papers ranging from the review of the sensing technology to design and applications of terahertz plasmonic devices to characterization and modeling of terahertz materials and interaction of terahertz radiation with matter. This book will be useful for scientists, engineers, and research leaders interested in terahertz materials, devices, systems, and applications. It is also recommended to graduate students working on terahertz science and technology.

We also gratefully acknowledge generous support of this workshop by the National Science Foundation (Award # 1443131).
